The Kardashev Scale is a method of measuring a civilization's level of technological advancement based on the amount of energy it is capable of harnessing. Proposed by the Soviet-Russian astrophysicist Nikolai Kardashev in 1964, the scale originally consisted of three types (I, II, and III), but has since been expanded to include Type IV and Type V.

Kardashev Type I, also known as a "Planetary Civilization," refers to a civilization that has the ability to harness and utilize all of the energy resources available on its home planet. This includes, but is not limited to, energy sources such as solar, wind, geothermal, hydropower, and biomass, as well as efficient management and control of the planet's energy resources.

Reaching Type I status implies that the civilization has achieved a high degree of technological advancement and societal organization, allowing for optimal use and distribution of energy resources around the globe. A Type I civilization might be able to control and even manipulate weather patterns or other natural phenomena by understanding and mastering the planet's natural energy flows.

While Earth currently does not qualify as a Type I civilization, our progress on the Kardashev Scale is measured in terms of the global energy consumption, which is increasing over time. As we develop advanced renewable energy technologies, reduce our dependence on non-renewable resources, and promote efficient energy usage and distribution, our civilization moves closer to achieving the Type I status.

The pursuit of this goal necessitates cooperation among nations, industries, and individuals to develop infrastructure, technologies, and policies that facilitate the generation and distribution of clean, sustainable energy. The concept of Plurigrid, with its principles of decentralized energy management, adaptability, and self-organization, would play a crucial role in propelling humanity toward Kardashev Type I and beyond.
